body:
Hi @leventov, 

I've processed your comments, and committed a new version. Please let me know if there are any further issues.

Cheers, Fokko
üëç
@jon-wei could you add to Release Notes that off-heap QTL cache shouldn't be used?
@leventov added an item to the release notes linking to this issue

@gianm thanks for pointing to #4004, I didn't notice it before. So if we don't use chunkPeriod on brokers, the recommendation is to set numProcessingThreads to 0?

Also I suppose that no buffers (neither intermediate result buffers nor merge buffers) or processing threads are needed on router nodes ever?
@jon-wei I would formulate it harder, like "must not be used because it is broken", but up to you
@leventov sure, I made the warning in the notes stronger

@gianm this feature is still here in the proposed approach, and the logic of "multiple runs" is not changed. To prevent situation when one or several expensive queries take _all_ available off-heap memory, dynamic constraints could be added, like no query could receive more memory, than current amount of free off-heap memory, divided by the current number of idle processing threads. In the worst case it would always divide resources as fair as the current approach (when all queries are equally expensive), but if cheaper queries are run in parallel with more expensive queries, it would allow for expensive queries to allocate more memory, while cheaper queries are not hurt.
@jon-wei thanks

> So if we don't use chunkPeriod on brokers, the recommendation is to set numProcessingThreads to 0?

I think that'll work, since I don't think anything else on the broker uses the processing pool.

> Also I suppose that no buffers (neither intermediate result buffers nor merge buffers) or processing threads are needed on router nodes ever?

I think this is true, because routers don't apply any of the toolchest functions, so they won't need processing pools.
Dropping a comment to follow the thread.

@cheddar @leerho @niketh as far as I can reason from public sources, this project is under development. According to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3892#issuecomment-276548114, could the query processing part be migrated first, and then the serde part? The processing part blocks #4422.

> To prevent situation when one or several expensive queries take all available off-heap memory, dynamic constraints could be added, like no query could receive more memory, than current amount of free off-heap memory, divided by the current number of idle processing threads.

That's the situation I was concerned about (an expensive query takes all available off-heap memory).

Here are more long tests.

```
Tests run: 15, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 105.67 sec - in io.druid.client.cache.CacheDistributionTest
```

@leventov @drcrallen 
our integration test build tries to download test segments from AWS, e.g.
```
"loadSpec":{"type":"s3_zip","bucket":"static.druid.io","key":"data/segments/twitterstream/2013-01-01T00:00:00.000Z_2013-01-02T00:00:00.000Z/2013-01-02T04:13:41.980Z_v9/0/index.zip"}
```

and fails with following error...

```
AWS profiles config file not found in the given path: /root/.aws/config\n\tat com.amazonaws.auth.profile.internal.ProfilesConfigFileParser.loadProfiles(ProfilesConfigFileParser.java:55)
\n\tat com.amazonaws.auth.profile.ProfilesConfigFile.loadProfiles(ProfilesConfigFile.java:129)
\n\tat com.amazonaws.auth.profile.ProfilesConfigFile.<init>(ProfilesConfigFile.java:97)
\n\tat com.amazonaws.auth.profile.ProfilesConfigFile.<init>(ProfilesConfigFile.java:77)
\n\tat com.amazonaws.auth.profile.ProfileCredentialsProvider.<init>(ProfileCredentialsProvider.java:45)

\n\tat io.druid.guice.AWSModule.getAWSCredentialsProvider(AWSModule.java:45)
```

I wonder if this is related to aws sdk change. Has anyone faced this issue ?

@himanshug internally we had to upgrade to aws-java-sdk 1.11 because of Spark incompatibility as far as I remember... and also to Jackson 2.6, that is not compatible with Hadoop.

But we didn't have such problems with aws-java-sdk 1.11
@leventov, @jon-wei, any further comments?

@leventov I guess its working for you probably because you're setting up AWS credentials (as described in http://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-java/v1/developer-guide/credentials.html ) in your environment.
For us, AWS usage is only in the integration testing and it used to work by default without supplying any credentials explicitly. Do you have any vanilla environment where you run the integration tests without any AWS credentials explicitly setup ?
@leventov I'm gonna try to do a build with `aws-java-sdk-ec2` reverted back to `aws-java-sdk` to check if this is really the cause.

@himanshug only integration tests that run in Travis, that has nothing to do with AWS S3.

Also could try to revert 1.10.77 -> 1.10.56
@gianm LGTM

@himanshug the line numbers in the stack trace you posted don't correspond to 1.10.77, but instead look more like 1.7.4. Perhaps that version is getting pulled in somehow for your build. Fwiw, the 0.10.1-rc1 tarball is bundled with:

```
druid-0.10.1-rc1/extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/aws-java-sdk-1.7.4.jar
druid-0.10.1-rc1/extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/hadoop-aws-2.7.3.jar
druid-0.10.1-rc1/lib/druid-aws-common-0.10.1-rc1.jar
druid-0.10.1-rc1/lib/aws-java-sdk-ec2-1.10.77.jar
druid-0.10.1-rc1/lib/aws-java-sdk-core-1.10.77.jar
```

So if you run out of the tarball, you should be getting 1.10.77 in the io.druid.guice.AWSModule code path.
Thanks for the report @scot0357. This should fail-fast with a better message in 0.10.0+, thanks to #3686. If you still see this sort of poor behavior with 0.10.0+ then please let us know.

@gian here are the jars in my build machine...

```
druid_dev/aws-java-sdk-core-1.10.77.jar
druid_dev/aws-java-sdk-ec2-1.10.77.jar
druid_dev/druid-aws-common-0.10.1-1497388461-ecb8bd9-1422.jar

druid_dev/extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/aws-java-sdk-1.7.4.jar
druid_dev/extensions/druid-hdfs-storage/hadoop-aws-2.7.3.jar
```

ok, i see that error in the stacktrace comes from file ProfilesConfigFileParser which belongs to aws-java-sdk-1.7.4 which is downloaded as a transitive dependency from hadoop-aws-2.7.3 in hdfs-storage module.

I believe it is coming from hadoop version change in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4116 .

continuing....  https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4313#issuecomment-309854006 and https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4313#issuecomment-309873993
does anyone know what aws properties are needed to be set to what values in integration testing environment to fix the situation ?
@gianm @leventov continuing the thread in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4116#issuecomment-309875183 .
@himanshug looks like a bug, aws-java-sdk should be excluded from hdfs-storage dependency

Looks like we endup getting different SDKs and this due to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4313/files#diff-600376dffeb79835ede4a0b285078036L182.
We use to pull the entire suite so we endup with the same aws sdk. IMO it will better to use one version rather having different version of core and sdk

> looks like a bug, aws-java-sdk should be excluded from hdfs-storage dependency

This dependency is used by HDFS storage when asked to load data from S3a.
@himanshug setting the version  to `1.10.77` at the hdfs pom file will bring down the correct jar. If that works we can have a global aws-version as fix.
@b-slim exclusion means that version resolver won't consider 1.7.4. The project may depend on aws-java-sdk-s3:1.10.77 globally. If it is binary-compatible in the functionality that hdfs-storage uses.

@leventov @b-slim 
yes, if hadoop-aws-2.7.3  can work with aws-java-sdk-s3:1.10.77  to have S3a support then I am in favor of adding that in top level pom and excluding aws-java-sdk in hdfs-storage pom from hadoop-aws dep.
an other way to fix this will be to make profile loading lazy initialized. What you guys think ?

@b-slim that might work for the problem i posted. but then its not great to have two different jars in the system that provide same functionality or conflict with each other. my understanding is that aws-java-sdk and aws-java-sdk-ec2 are in that boat . are they ?
@himanshug i have tested it with 1.10.56 against an internal 2.7.3 (patched that is more like 2.8 ish) and it worked, i guess we can go that route of having one version at  the top.
@b-slim ok, let me also test whether that solves the original problem i posted. will update.
@b-slim if you know that would fix original problem too, then go ahead and send the PR.
@Fokko also please don't amend commits in the future, add more commits to branch
@gianm I think 0.10.2 is going to be 0.11.0, so this PR should probably just not go to master, only to 0.10.1

I don't think there's an issue in 0.10.1, since #4394 wasn't included there. I'm still ok with this patch in master, it makes life a little easier for people upgrading, and that's always good. (just because we _can_ break an API doesn't mean we _should_)

Oops, 0.10.1 did include #4394, I was looking at 0.10.0. Point about master still stands though.

If we merge it to master I can do a backport to 0.10.1 after that. Or if we decide not to merge to master it could go directly to 0.10.1.
@himanshug @b-slim does that mean we need to change something for 0.10.1 (rc2)?
Is druid-api module still needed?
Maybe not. The purpose was to put everything that was a public API in one package, but it turns out that there are public APIs in other packages too.
+1 for going directly to 0.10.1
@gianm most likely, yes... m gonna test https://github.com/himanshug/druid/commit/9632b0cb8fe9beb60d0a837af951238b5ffb1219
@leventov Thanks. This really depends on the project, some projects are forcing it, other projects dislike it. But I won't amend in future PR's of Druid.
i see you have already this https://github.com/himanshug/druid/commit/9632b0cb8fe9beb60d0a837af951238b5ffb1219

I resolved this problemÔºåset mapreduce.job.classloader=true,Hadoop's classloder and application's classloader is isolated,Hadoop's classloader only load hadoop jar,don't include hive's jar,so cause classnotfound exception,So you can't enable this option.
If disable this option will cause jackson json conflict with CDH. Refer to [http://druid.io/docs/0.10.0/operations/other-hadoop.html](url),recompile and using shade plugin to mask a fat jar, you can choose one of them.I choose shade plugin,it is a relatively simple way.
I cleaned up the wording a bit, to clarify that PublicApis can have new non-default methods added to an interface and this is not considered a breakage (because they are not meant to be subclassed).

@gianm could you please review this pr?
fixed by #3521.

Thanks a lot for your suggestions @drcrallen .  With your input and my practice,  I came up with the solution below.

Druid roles can be categorized into 2 different groups:
* **Controller**: coordinator/middleManager  --  limited workers for each controller role for one cluster. 
* **Worker**: broker/historical  -- large number of workers is needed for one cluster with hundreds of machines

So on first stage of druid on yarn project, I only take worker role (broker/historical) into consideration.

Details as below:

![druidonyarnarchitecture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16383228/27428940-28e18136-5776-11e7-8459-19758d584af8.png)

One application master for each module.
1. Druid client send request to yarn resource manager to start up  app master
2. Yarn resource manager start the app master
3. App manager ask resource for broker/historical according to certain strategies
4. ResourceManager return the resource and app manager will get connection with those node manager
5. App manager ask related node manager to start broker/historical
6. broker/historical register themselves into zookeeper after startup for failover senerio
7. App manager watch the related zookeeper path.  If any broker/historical fails due to OOM or other exception, app manager will try to restart it.

Currently, Druid has its constrains as a distributed system.
**Broker**  
1.  Users need to connect to brokers to query druid.  So broker ip and port are exposed to either VIP or user directly.  So broker ip and port can't be changed.
2.  If use VIP as load balancer,  all broker would have to start on the same port.  Thus only one worker can be started per node.

**Historical**  
1. Historical works as local cache for data.   It takes some time to download data from HDFS to local disk.  So it's better to restart historical on the same node when failover.
2. Currently, all historical use the same dir to store data.  So only one historical can be started per node.

Due to above reasons, druid is not a normal distributed systems.  The druid application manager needs to be able to support at least 2 worker distribution strategies:
1. Exclusive -- one broker/historical per node
2. Normal -- workers can be distributed on any node with enough resource

On first stage,  I'll focus on the exclusive strategy.  The second one needs more druid code modification.  And also,  for failover strategy,  workers will be start up at the same node before it dead abnormally.

From long term,  druid broker and historical should be able to support the normal strategy.  And the solutions to this problems are quiet easy.

![druidonyarn-broker](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16383228/27428904-07f18b56-5776-11e7-999e-690fafa5adbb.png)

*  For brokers, use a proxy to distribute the querys
*  For historical,  app manager will asign a data dir for each historical.

Perhaps above functions would be done in stage two.  

 Let me know if you have any questions or ideas.
üëç

For query routing we do have a druid router node that can be used. Router will discover brokers via ZK service. So this can be a viable way to hide the complexity of having fix pool of ip/ports for brokers.
Also this PR fails some tests, not flaky, related to this change.
@wangbokun what did you configure as 5368709120? It's more than available integer range (5 billion vs 2 billion)
@himanshug could you restart build from travis page? it's 1 more click for you, but OTOH it doesn't create email notifications for PR subscribers
@kaijianding you are doing a lot of PRs, could you also review other people's PRs? And then become a committer?
Sure, will review other's PRs and glad to hear that I'm close to being a committer @leventov

@kaijianding I'm not sure about closeness and it's not for me to decide because I'm not a PMC member, but making reviews is essential because it's a painful aspect in the project that not enough reviews are done. When you are making a lot of PRs you demand reviews but not "contribute them back".

related to #2252  and #3294

Hi @Niteesh, thank you for the contribution.
This patch failed to pass unit tests. Would you check it please?
Great question. Can you explain some more on what your needs for authentication and access rights are?
We need something similar to what Kylin provides. [Kylin Enable Security with LDAP.](http://kylin.apache.org/docs/howto/howto_ldap_and_sso.html)

The same task cannot be added to TaskQueue multiple times. See [TaskQueue.add()](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/indexing-service/src/main/java/io/druid/indexing/overlord/TaskQueue.java#L310).

@erikdubbelboer Did you find a resolution to this issue ? We are running into the same issue, our entire pipeline is in UTC and we are querying in the Asia/Singapore timezone. 
Segment Granularity : PT4H, Query Granularity : Hour.

I left a comment but it's gone now. 

If we do this then it's not iso anymore. I spoke with @gianm and he mentioned you can specify a joda time string for the format.

As such I propose making sure that functionality works, and avoid having custom time format handlers for non standard formats built into the code.

@drcrallen thanks for this catch. I think not only for file names, but in many and probably sometimes hardly predictable cases it may be important not to emit something wrong instead of failing, so I renamed `safeFormat()` to `unimportantSafeFormat()` and use it only for logging and exception messages, and added `StringUtils.format()` which simply delegates to `String.format()` with `Locale.ENGLISH`, which now used everywhere else.

BTW it this `safeFormat()` was protection from programming errors, IntelliJ has inspections which verify format strings and arguments of arbitrary format-like methods, that could be used to effectively exclude such errors. The few places where it doesn't apply are `StringFormatExtractionFn` and `IndexerSQLMetadataStorageCoordinator`.
